qas.question: What Latin word does the English word translation come from?
What languages use equivalents of the English term "translation" that come from the same Latin source?
What does Latin's traducere mean in English?
Slavic and Germanic languages also use a similar loanword from what source?
What does the Dutch word "vertaling" roughly translate to?
What French word does the English word translation come from?
What languages use equivalents of the German term "translation" that come from the same Latin source?
What does Russia's traducere mean in English?
What does the American word "vertaling" roughly translate to?
What language is always derived from Latin?

context: The <b9_0>English<b9_0/> word "translation" derives from the Latin <a0_0><b5_0>translatio<b5_0/><a0_0/> (which itself comes from trans- and from fero, the supine form of which is latum—together meaning "a carrying across" or "a bringing across"). The modern <a1_0><b6_0>Romance<b6_0/><a1_0/> languages use equivalents of the English term "translation" that are derived from that same Latin source or from the alternative Latin traducere (<a2_0>"<b7_0>to lead across<b7_0/>"<a2_0/> or "to bring across"). The Slavic and Germanic languages (except in the case of the Dutch equivalent, "vertaling"—a <a4_0>"<b8_0>re-language-ing<b8_0/>"<a4_0/>) likewise use calques of these <a3_0>Latin<a3_0/> sources.
